DIV1.P: THE COUNT OF BURGUNDY: A COMEDY OF KOTZEBUE. IN FOUR ACTS.
TRANSLATED FROM THE GERMAN, BY CHARLES SMITH.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED FOR CHARLES SMITH AND S. STEPHENS. 1800.
THE AUTHOR'S INTRODUCTION TO THE FIRST VOLUME.

ON this collection of my theatrical productions, I have little to say. As they had the good fortune of meeting with the public's approbation, they will un∣doubtedly displease the reviewers. I am so well ac∣customed to the asperity of those censors against pub∣lic approbation; to their illiberal hints against the morality of my pieces; to their evident endeavours to attack the weaker parts, and still more to discolour the good, that I shall not lose a single word on that subject.

I know better than any reviewer that I do not pro∣duce master pieces, and that, as a dramatic writer, I deserve but a subordinate rank. My productions are chiefly calculated for stage effect; they obtain that end, and in this point of view they ought to be judged. The public, which, for years back, has done me justice, will, I trust, furnish me in future with oil against the bitings of these musquetoes.

Some have objected to the Count of Burgundy, as appearing in the third act suddenly too accomplished. But has not that rather been the fault of the actor, who was unable to penetrate deep enough into the author's meaning?—If the young Count brings it forth as declamation what he has to say in the third act, to the people, to his mother, &c. &c.; if he rai∣ses his sentiments into sentences by ostentation in his
expression; if he does not speak it carelessly, just so as his feeling lays it upon his tongue; if he permits himself but one moment, in accent and manners, to play the hero; then indeed the audience must find a striking difference between him and the child of na∣ture in the two first acts. I am sorry to learn, that most of the young actors perform the Count's part in that manner, but that is not my fault. It was my duty not to insert any thing in the third act that might be contradictory to the words of the first and second, and this duty, I trust, I have fulfilled. If they are spoken, as I thought them to myself; the audience will recognize the hermit's son in the reigning Count.

False Shame is a subject, which, I believe, has for the first time been brought upon the stage; and this fault being the source of so many evils in this world, I hope to have acquired some merit by inspiring ma∣ny a good heart with confidence to confidence.

The idea of La Peyrouse, suddenly rose within me, when, some time ago, I read in the public prints that the wise of this unfortunate man, had embarked, in search of him on uninhabited coasts. My imagina∣tion followed her to sea, created interesting situa∣tions, and lost itself in the empire of possibilities. But that in the plan of this piece—in spite of the most careful evasion of every thing improper—an error against morality should have been found, is a delica∣cy, to which I was not prepared.
As to the Wild Youth—it is but a Christmas a∣musement, and is not to represent any thing else.

DIV1.HEAD: TRANSLATOR'S PREFACE.
DIV1.P: To lay before the public a faithful translation of all the dramatic productions of the celebrated Kotze∣bue, who is justly styled the GERMAN SHAKESPEAR, is the design of the present undertaking.

The difficulty of translating from the German into the English language is very considerable, as has been sufficiently verified by the many unsuccessful attempts which have been made for that purpose.

But if there is, in general, a difficulty in translating from so copious a language as the German, it must obviously be considerably encreased when we at∣tempt dramatic writings, in which in order to do jus∣tice to the original it is essentially necessary, that we should be well acquainted with the very genius and spirit of that language.

To represent the meaning of KOTZEBUE precisely as he intended it, shall be the main aim throughout this publication; and if in accomplishing so impor∣tant an object the language should in some instances be found rather deficient in point of , I doubt not of obtaining a ready excuse from a can∣did public.

To the intelligent reader, whether he be in the ha∣bit of seeing , it is of no moment what in the per∣formance: but when his down to peruse the author, he will
every effusion of his heart in its real purity. He wishes neither for curtailment nor alterations—much less for any additions, which being often the produc∣tions of men of inferior talents, greatly diminish the splendor of the original author.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: Brother PETER, an hermit at the foot of the Alps.
Count HUGO of Werdenberg, Governor of Arles.

DIV1.HEAD: THE COUNT OF BURGUNDY.
SCENE.
DIV1.P: A woody country at the foot of the Swiss mountains In the back ground an hermitage; opposite an open chapel; between both a garden fence. In the fore ground a grass bench underneath an apple-tree.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: PETER sitting upon the bench making a basket of wil∣low branches. HENRY on the opposite side splits wood, singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: This song pleases you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Yes, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: You like it better than the singing of the matins.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Much better.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter,
SP.P: And are not afraid of such a sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Father? Can't be a sin. This song seems to be as pleasing to you as to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: What do you mean by this?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: When you sing HoraAn hourly exercise of devotion is convents,, you are cast down. But when you sing the battle song of Murgarten or the Victory song of Sempach, then your cheeks glow and your eyes burn like the wax candle before the holy virgin.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Have you discovered that?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Still more: You have a song of the sword of justice, and the shield of faith; you love to sing that best, because it speaks of swords and shields.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter,
SP.P: Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A sword is a fine thing. As to the shield, one may do without.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Think you so my brave boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Heury.
SP.P: Had that valiant Knight Erlach a shield, when he fought at Donnerbuhel?— (swinging the hatchet over his head) ha! it is to me as if I heard the trumpet's sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Who tells you that you are a Swiss?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My heart—my thirst for actions!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Have patience, my son! your hour will arrive.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A creeping hour, slow like old mother Ger∣traud. I long to meet it.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Behold the apples on the tree; are they ripe▪

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Not yet, but soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Sweet fruits, for those who can wait.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why have you kindled within me a flame, that finds no nourishment in these forests and, consumes me?—Why telling me so much of battles and fights that man and horse day and night parade before my eyes? as often as our old stallion neighs in the stable, I look for a lance and touch a rosary. As often as the guard on the Castle's steeple sounds the horn, I run for a sword and lay hold of an ax. Each great action makes the blood flow to my heart and brings water in my eyes. Every valiant knight I would press to my heart, and split the head of every scoundrel with the battle ax.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Such I wanted you to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: For what? for whom?—Have you taught me so many sciences, to sing them before our shep∣herds at their festivals? Whoever brings up a falcon for the chase must not confine him in a cage.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: As long as he wears a cap he is too young.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Let us hear, how old?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Eighteen years and upwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P:
See here father! (he splits a log with one
stroke) how old was the boy who made this stroke, do you think that an enemy's head is harder than this trunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: strength belongs to youth. Even in this wil∣low branch is juice and strength, but it is pliable. Obe∣dience ornaments the boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Is the bow to become slack, wet it; give me herbs to cool my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Go, try your courage with bears and wolves.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: They are but trifling robbers as long as men exist. Let me go to the castle. Knight Cuno long since wished me to become his armour bearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Will you leave your old father alone in this wilderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You are a pious man, the whole vicinity re∣veres the pious brother Peter,—who would hurt you?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Enough, Henry it is not becoming you to be Cuno's armour bearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Is not the race of Hallwyll noble and re∣nowned?—and who am I then, that I should be asha∣med to learn of Cuno to bear arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Dive not into matters, which time only un∣folds. A youth may bear arms but not keep a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Father, why humble me? Is a noble name my inheritance, why will you withhold the treasure from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: To deliver it now into your hands, would be depriving you of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A problem—always problems! why has the father so little confidence in his son?—have you fled from the field of honour into a desart; have you con∣verted your armour into a hermit's habit; and why—has power forced you to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: And, suppose you have hit the point?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Then give me a sword, I will avenge you!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No, son, revenge slowly follows vice and has wings only to attain virtue. The wished for hour is not yet come.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Allow me at least to travel into foreign countries, to prepare myself by actions for your re∣venge.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Would'st soon forget in the tumult of the world your old father and his wilderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You are not in earnest. I love you and the wilderness where I grew up; I love the apple-tree, which you have planted on my second birth day; and the grave upon which you used to weep; I love the wood stream, our summer bath, and the little garden, where the plants grow under my hands. Above all, I love Miss Elsbeth, who was shooting at my side like a young cedar, and whose cheeks glow like the castle windows when the evening sun gilds them. Also do I love old Cuno, because Elsbeth calls him father. Not to forget mother Gertraud! often have I plagued her in return for her nice cakes. Yes, I love all, all.—The road into the world is the road to honor; that in∣to the mountains the small path to tranquility. Suffer only one twig of laurels to bloom round my head. Af∣ter that I am with you and lay myself to Elsbeths feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Water your plants, and if you grow too warm, cool yourself in the wood stream, till the time-piece, calls you to higher actions—who knows how soon?—a short while yet—perhaps fortune favors you before the leaves fall off these trees. My basket is finished. You forgot by your prattling your days work. There in the garden is work enough. Split your wood and then come to assist me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: HENRY alone. Looks after his father, shakes his head and goes to his work.

SP.P:
Very comprehensible. He has emptied the cup, how should he know what a thirsty man feels—tranqui∣lity—a refreshing draught to the old, to youth poison—were but the wood in the forest harder, and requi∣red more strength to split it, or were—(he looks up) hallo! there climbs Elsbeth down the footpath—God knows how she contrives it, let me but see her and I am contented with every thing—She leaps like a roe—old
Gertraud behind her, laying hold of every branch—Shall I plague the girl?—I owe her something for the large stone she threw into the water th' other day, which wetted me from head to foot—where shall I hide my∣self—hush?—on the tree! (throwing away the ax he climbs up the apple-tree).

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Miss ELSBETH leaps upon the STAGE, looking anxious∣ly around her. Mother GERTRAUD appears a mo∣ment after. Her coughing is heard at a distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertraud.
SP.P: My God, Miss, do not run so fast, I am out of breath?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsbeth.
SP.P: Rest yourself, dear mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: I thought so! shall I again rest here? why just here?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: It is a friendly spot.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Friendly? I don't know that. The sun can hardly penetrate the high apple-trees.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well; that makes it cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Gentr.
SP.P: Yes, as cool as our castle cellar. Think you the blood in my veins flows as rapid as yours?—you leap like a fish in the rivulet, walk on thousand feet like a cellar worm. You would already have tumbled down the rock a thousand times if you were not pro∣tected by the dear angels of heaven. Scarcely day light appears, and you are out of your bed, forget ave Maria and rosary, swallow your morning soup as if it was a bitter medicine: than she calls and squalls: Mother Gertraud shall we take a walk? "ah Miss, this trou∣blesome cough"—the free air will do you good—"I have not said my mourning prayers yet."—under God's free heaven you can pray more fervent—and so she lays hold of my clothes, tears me, draws me along—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Be not angry mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P:
And whither does she carry me?—always to this place.—We are scarcely got into the garden,
where I stop to eat currents—when, away she runs, jumping from rock to rock, like a wild goat, leaping like a squirrel from tree to tree, and all at once returns again to the same place, and old mother Gertraud may call till she is hoarse—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Have you done scolding, mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Well, say, what secret treasure do you look for here. True you are a Sunday's child.—What are you looking for so anxiously: You turn your head like a bird after red berries?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do you not conceive why I'm here? I seek herbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: They grow on the mountains better than here.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: see there, white root, it only grows in the shade, and—wild clover for father's soup.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Indeed! and the poisonous marigold, will you put that into the soup too?—Miss! Miss! the marigold is an useless weed and the young fellow that lives here is also an useless weed; but you are a won∣der-flower that must bloom in secret, to give pleasure to God and man.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What do you mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: see the poor girl understands me not. I'll make it clearer to you. You are running after that young boy here, Henry, do you understand it better now.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Fy? Mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Fy, I say too, the devil lays snares for the innocent. Your father shall hear of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well, I do no evil.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: No evil? the unfortunate child! She can scarcely repeat a psalm or scribble her name, and yet will know to distinguish good from evil. Think you we find out the evil by the cloven foot or the dra∣gon's tail? never—the honey which Jonathan suck∣ed from the stump was sweet. Follow my advice, Miss, I mean it honest with you; do not approach the hermitage too near.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You are peevish, mother, why should I not visit the pious Peter?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P:
Aye, aye, that pious Peter has a son with
whose is not right. Has not that fellow last Sunday desired me to spin, and even during the mass I often catch him squinting at you from behind his hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: He does not squint, he has a fine large pair of eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: so much the worse! I wish to God he was blind and lame! take care Miss! if Walter of Blonay should hear of it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Well, you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Every one may judge my actions, and what has Chevalier of Blonay to do with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Your Bridegroom.—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: O! We are not yet come so far.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr,
SP.P: But. with the help of God, we shall come so far. Blonay is a fine knight, has three stately castles.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Good! the sun shines also upon huts.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Gold and silver—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Can he do more than eat till he is satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: You talk like an ignorant girl; but when you see once the golden chains and the precious bridal or∣naments—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do we walk and jump easier in golden chains?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Jumping is then altogether at an end. You will then walk in stately array, a page bearing your train, and a noble youth leading your horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: (peevishly). Leave me undisturbed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Patience, Patience, the children's shoes are not worn out yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I am no more a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: At the age of fifteen we still are with one leg in the cradle—Go young lady, if your father returns from hunting and finds you not at home, he will growl.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: It is false, Mother; my father is good, he ne∣ver growls.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he is but too good. Along! along! I already hear the horns.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I wo'nt.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What will you do then?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Stay here, to rest myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: (ironically) And look for herbs?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I am fatigued. (She sits down upon the bench).

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Obstinate child what shall I do.—(to herself) fortunately the boy is not at hand, now there is no danger (loud) rest yourself then in the name of God! I will go meanwhile into the chapel and repeat an ave Maria.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do that, Mother, and pray for me also.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Yes, yes, it's necessary, it is easier to hold an eel, by the tail than to guard a young girl.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: ELSBETH, and HENRY on the tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Where can he be? Is the lazy boy asleep yet? Shall I throw a dry branch in∣to the hut?

DIV2.STAGE: Henry. (lets an apple fall upen her).

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What's that?—an apple, (she takes it up and looks at it), is not ripe yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Elbs.
SP.P: Again? (jumps up) Does a hobgoblin make jest of me— (she perceives Henry) O! you rogue! down from the tree! I shall pay you for that. (whilst Henry gets down, Elsbeth tears up some grass and flowers, puts them into her apron, and as he approaches her she throws one handfull after another at his face.) This is for the first apple!—this for the sesond—this for your listening, and this for your always plaguing me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Elsbeth! Elsbeth! cease or I kiss you.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Yes, you may kiss, mother Gertraud is in the chapel, and if she turns her head she can see us.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: She will not turn her head.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You! I'll run into the chapel.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: run if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Henry. I shall be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You must not get angry— (he lets her go). Why will you not give me a kiss?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Have I not lately kissed you; when the rivu∣let was swelled up and you carried the old man over the small bridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: That is a long time since.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And when you took that poor boy out of the water did I not kiss you then?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Oh! that's still longer ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: As often as you do a good action you shall have a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I wish to do always good. Is it my fault that not every day boys fall into the water, or old men wish to get over a bridge?—Kiss me.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I Won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I know why you won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well, why?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Walter of Blonay is a fine knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Those precious golden chains.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Henry, I go into the chapel.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Go, go; you will soon enough go there to be married to Walter.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Old mother Gertraud has put that into your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Is it not true then?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well my father dropt a few words about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: And they fell upon your heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What's that to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: True—it is nothing to me—I am a poor youth—I love you and that's all—When you come down from the castle with music and a stately train, suddenly your horse will become shy and —what is that? you will ask—oh nothing! poor Henry lays on the road and has grieved himself to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Fy! Henry! fy! that was naughty of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry▪
SP.P: And if it was true?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I believe you weep—Dear Henry kiss me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: No, I will not kiss you now, you only want to pay me for the grief I shall have to endure.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You are a fool▪ I shall not marry at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Will you promise that?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I'll rather go into a convent than to Walter of Blonay.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My eyes have never beheld that man, but I hate him heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: For shame! we must not hate any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If he should once fall into the water—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Would'st you not help him out? Look at me!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: (is going to say no, but a glance at Elsbeth, makes it impossible for him) I would—for your sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: No, for God's sake! To serve friends is no mer∣it, but to save enemies is a piece of entrance money with st. Peter.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: She speaks like an Abbot.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Be now again merry. Come let us look for herbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I must split wood.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I'll help you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You help me! ha! ha! ha! you can scarce∣ly lift the ax.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: O ho! I can draw my father's massy sword out of the scabbard.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well then try. (he gives her a hatchet, she makes a few aukward cuts, whilst he with the utmost dex∣terity splits some large logs.)

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: It won't do.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I thought so. You will cut your foot. But see how quick I do it. When you are present, it is to me as if I could split rocks.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Have you ever heard it, Henry, that when one loves and shares labour it goes easier out of hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I have never heard that, but it may be very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Come and help me to seek herbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What kind of herbs?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Whiteroot and speedwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I don't know them.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I will show them to you. See, this is white∣root.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: O, enough of them grow here.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: There is a whole handfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Fool, these are not the right kind—They are poisonous.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Throw them trifles away, and let us chat. If I should once be wounded in battle, then you may seek roots, and prepare a salve.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Aye, aye, what is it to me if you are wounded?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: So! you would leave me helpless!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: There is brother Burkard in the convent, he understands medicine.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I cannot bear monks about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Take a wife, then. It is becoming a faithful wife to nurse her master.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Right Elsbeth I'll make you my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You me? ha! ha! ha!—how will you do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: First I will go to Italy and Germany, to Bur∣gundy and Wallis, there I'll fight bravely, that people will talk of me; and a valiant prince make me a knight; then I will present myself before your father and say: Valiant knight, give me the graceful baroness Elsbeth to wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And when the father says yes?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well, then we send for the monk at the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And me you will not ask at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I hope you will not say no.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Who knows it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: will you say no?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Fy! don't look at me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Dear Elsbeth will you say no

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: (sinks into his arms.)

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Now, here we have it! holy Aguesia! and all the eleven thousand virgins! assist me!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What is the matter, mother Gertraud?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And you dare to ask? You wicked children! What have I seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Where? where?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Have you not been in each others arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Now? and what more?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: More still? heavens beware! Boy, would'st push the crime still farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Crime?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Whilst I lay there piously upon my knees, and pray one rosery after another, satan here carries on his game,

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Satan has not been here.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Let that be as it may, mother you know how much I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: You? love me, as a wolf loves the dog that guards the sheep.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You found us arm in arm, is that not better than hatred and quarrel?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: No it is not better—I would rather you had scratched out one anothers eyes, there would be less danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: You do not understand that, young lady—I must know that better: and in short—I shall this very day ac∣quaint your father with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Be not so peevish, mother Gertraud, (he picks up the apples which he dropped upon Elsbeth) There take a pair of fine apples.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Let me alone with your sour apples.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well then, give to the apples some of your ripeness, and you will both have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: I believe the boy is mocking me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: God forbid! is it my fault that the apples are not ripe?—Stop, I recollect, (he feels his pocket) see here a fine picture of the holy Maria, finely coloured, this I present you with.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: I will not have it. Away Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Aye, aye, is this the mother Gertraud of whom every body speaks so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What have they told you of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: That in your youthful days you were the finest damsel in the whole valley.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Paperlapapp.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Poets had exhausted their wit on your black eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Who told them to do so?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You was called the beautiful Gertraud.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: God had blessed me with a fine figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Old and young were staring at you, when at a dance, you turned yourself in graceful windings.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Yes, yes, that's true enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: And you were, with all that, so chaste and pi∣ous, so modest and affable—

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: The Rogue! one cannot be angry with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: are you reconciled again, mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Dear Mother! do not be angry with poor Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I love so much to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I love her so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Is it punishable, to be fond of one anothers company?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Is it sinful, to love each other?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Children! children! you do not understand that. Satan often perverts Love into boys tricks. You, Henry, may be a very good boy, but none knows whence thou comest or whither thou goest. But Miss Elsbeth is a Knight's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Aye, my father was formerly a Knight too.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Your father is that pious Brother Peter; of whose knighthood I know nothing. In short it is high time to separate you, before any misfortune happens.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What misfortune can happen then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Away, Young Lady! away! You are always so wonderful quick in coming down and so slow in going up.—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: See there, mother, a Pilgrim passing through the wood.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What is that Pilgrim to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: He comes perhaps from the Holy sepulchre. I love to hear news from foreign countries.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P:
Curiosity fits not a young damsel. We often
hear more in one hour than we are able to forget all our life time.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: A few moments only, dear mother, are you afraid of that old Greybeard?

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: BRUNO, in Pligrim's habit. The FORMER.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Blessed be Jesus Christ!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: In all eternity amen!

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Can you inform me where dwells the pious Brother Peter?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: You are on the very spot.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Thanks, mother, I come from the Convent Einsiedeln, A famous place in switzerland where Pilgrims of all parts of Europe resort to. in passing below through the village I heard much of his pious conduct; and resolved to go out of my way, to confess to him. Where may I find him?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Here is his Son, he can inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: his Son! this youth his Son? (with emotion to Henry.) God bless you! my eyes become bright in beholding you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I thank you, Venerable Man; but I am not so pious as my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: No, indeed! that he is not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: the tender sprig is become a Stately tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Have you ever known me before?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: It may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Have you ever been here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: often have I been here—constantly!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I forgot your features. Be that as it may! can I serve you in any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: If you do it willingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I am always ready to serve.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: I may hereafter remind you of your word. For the present tell me where is your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If you look over yonder fence you will see him in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Let us he gone, Miss! me thinks I hear your father's hunting horns.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I am going, Farewell Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I shall conduct you part of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: It's unnecessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: To the place only, where a piece of the broken rock barricades the footpath. There I'll help you over.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: I have often got over without help.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The rain has made the ground slippery, and on the right hand the precipice. No—indeed, I shall not let you go alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: O heaven! It is surprising how much he is concerned that I should not slip. But I guess—you may accompany us this time but not farther than to the large rock.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Good bye, pious Pilgrim! if you come to see us at the Castle, I will treat you with a glass of our best wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: I thank you, lovely Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: In the garden you will find my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: God be with you! children children! don't run so fast.

Blessing on my Country! the lovely youth, uncorrupt∣ed in soul and body. No sickly plant out of a princely garden; a fresh tree full of juice and strength. It was fortunate, perhaps, for you Burgundy, that it so happened. No monk has made his neck to bend, nor a prostitute de∣prived him of the youthful red of his cheeks. But I forget that dear old Gentleman, so much was I surprised at the appearance of the youth—my intelligence is long looked
for yet unexpected.— (he approaches the garden fence) Is that he—who is so busy digging the ground?—It fits him well—yet the sword fitted him better.—O how grief and age have altered him! grey hair, deep wrinkles on his fore∣head—but 'tis he!—heart, my beating heart! Yes 'tis he!— (he calls) Chevalier, Hans of Bonstetten!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Who calls?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Hans of Bonstetten!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Great God! who calls?

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: PETER comes in great agitation upon the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Pilgrim! who disclosed to you my name?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Have you forgot my voice?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Apparition! eighteen years ago I would have sworn it was my faithful brother Bruno.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: 'Tis he.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Hah! welcome friend's voice. How sweet it sounds into the unaccustomed ear!—rise, let me press you to the heart—that once more beats youthful.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: My good old master.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: O what a variegated crowd of images—the sound of your voice creates before my eyes!—how am I—where am I?—One single familiar tone has converted eigh∣teen years into a dream. I see myself again in the circle of my family, see brothers and sisters about me, hold my dear wife in my arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Where is she, that I may salute her.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Ah! I have buried her! yonder hill covers the dear remains. Eight long years the noble Agnez assist∣ed me in rearing plants in this wilderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Oh that God had prolonged her days 'till the rising of a new sun.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Speak, what brings you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: The dear pledge, entrusted to you by fate he lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: He lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Then put on your armour! away! away! to Burgundy.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Is he dead, that robber of the throne?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: O'erwhelmed with curses he has descended to his forefathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Our time is come at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: So show ourselves—still flow the tears of the people's love on the grave of the murdered father.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henry, your hour is arrived. Is, Matilda liv∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: She lives in the solitude of a convent—the ma∣ternal heart knows nothing of the strong ties which link her to this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Messenger of heaven! after so many hopeless days, you have refreshed me with a salutary dew—I shall quit you, dear solitude—quit you, grave of my beloved wife!—I thank you God, that for the welfare of my coun∣try you have lengthened my days!—Come, Bruno, come into that chapel, to bring to the Eternal the offerings of our hearts!—and then let us clean the armour that has been rosting these eighteen years. (He takes him by the hand and leads him into the chapel.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: PETER and BRUNO with spades; they dig a hole into the ground under a tree, talking during their labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: AND so he is constantly: noble hearted, good, full of sensibility, and thirst for action.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Does he never desire to know your fate?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: O yes, he is never tired of asking—My answers are oracles. His being my pupil only, never enters his mind. And indeed I love him as my child!

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Have you not given him a second life? With∣out you, his brother's mournful fate would have befallen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I am not born for a pilgrim, and he found that out. I love better to speak of battles than to read a le∣gend. He is better acquainted with the history of his country than that of the holy Antonius in the wilderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Hush! methinks I hear something. If he was listening—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Listening? Good Bruno, you come from a princely court. Here in this wilderness we listen to nightingales only. Henry is far enough. I have sent him to the lake to catch a mess of fish—I was fearful lest his questions would disturb the sensation which, at this work, I wish to nourish—Enough! Do you see the trunk? Let us go and lift it up, it is not heavy. (They descend into the hole and lift up the box) hah! how la∣bour and frugality add to the strength, which is absorbed by age. Indeed, Bruno, eighteen years ago I lifted this trunk with less ease than to day.—There it is—I see it again, and think of the last look I gave it on covering it with earth—my wife was then at my side—at this tree she was leaning—the tree is green yet—Oh!— (he endeavors to collect himself) here is the key—cov∣ered with rust—we shall open the lock easier with the hatchet. (After some efforts the lid opens. Peter drops his utensils, turns himself, puts both his hands before his face, weeps aloud.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: What ails you, good master, you weep?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Ah, Bruno! my wife's necklace first struck my view. Take it away and put it in your pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No! no! I cannot see it in strange hands, (pressing it fervently to his bosom) In these ornaments I conducted her to the marriage altar. In these ornaments she swore to me eternal fidelity, and she has kept her vow—till death—My lovely faithful Agnez! the chain which once adorned your neck— (he puts it in his bosom) it shall never be wrested from my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: You are moved, good Bruno.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: I remember her benefactions. Twenty years ago, when illness stretched me on my bed, her attention comforted me.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Twenty years have elapsed since, and you recol∣lect it still with grateful tears. But I, to whom she was every thing: I, whose hut she converted into a palace—Oh, what a precious jewel is a good housewife. Enough, Bruno, our country calls—be silent, my heart!—See here the swathing clothes in which Henry lay, when he in Agnez's arms escaped the bloody scene.—This here is the ring with the seal of the old Count—This the cup with the arms of Burgundy, which many a foreign prince took from my hands to take a welcome draught—Here underneath my armour, with helmet and sword—Let us see whether I can handle it yet— (he draws the sword, swing∣ing it over his head)—For God and my country! There is strength yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Henry's name will conquer his people, not the sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: True brother, a son finds his way easy to the throne, when it is marked by the father's benefactions.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Master, I see people com∣ing down from the mountain.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Let us carry the trunk into the chapel. If they are the women from the castle there will be no end to their questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Methinks they lead an old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: perhaps the old knight Cuno. A brave man. A little too talkative. What pain it is to move the lips when the heart is affected. Come, assist.
SP.STAGE: (They carry the box into the hut.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Miss ELSBETH. Soon after CUNO and Mother GER∣TRAUD.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Two men went into the hut, carrying something that looked like a coffin: But Henry was not with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Elsbeth!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Here, father!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You run about like a colt; that is not becoming; you are fifteen years old, and should begin to walk modestly and softly.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Why is a step more modest than a leap?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: A lively caper at a dance I should have no ob∣jection to.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You carry your head so high and free; it shakes like a weather cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And the eyes! the eyes! they turn about like a flame in a wirlwind.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And the hands fly up and down, like the wings of a windmill.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And the hairs hang wildly round the neck, like cedar-twigs.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: One finds fault with this, another with that! how shall I do to please them?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: A modest young woman should trip it smooth and softly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Not look about, but blink.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: The hands must rest modestly in the lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: The hairs, neatly curled close to the neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: mother, get yourself a girl cut out of wood,

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Naughty child! am I then cut out of wood? In my youth how often have I been at banquets sitting so stiff that they had to put a feather to my mouth, to know whether I was alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Banquets are no pleasure parties. Look at the Redbreast here in the bush, how it leaps and sings; above a Mag-Pie chattering, but it seems to care for nothing, father,—you are fatigued.
SP.STAGE: (she wipes the sweat from his forehead.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: How you made me cough, running after you down the mountain.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: That's always her way; at every hedge she leaves a piece of cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And I dont know why you tore me out of my arm chair?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Mother Gertraud would not go with me, and alone I dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Aye, aye, alone! when the Bee is out of the basket, there are ten swallows behind to catch it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: sit down, father, on the grass bench. So—lean against the tree—slumber—I will link a few branches together that the sun cannot discommode you— (she is busy in placing the old man comfortably) Now? Is it not better here than between the cold walls of the Castle? in that cool leather arm chair? I'll go to gather herbs for your Sallad, cresses, sorrel and spoon-wort.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Miss Elsbeth, where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Let her go.

SP.SPEAKER: Gernr.
SP.P: Quite alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno,
SP.P: Children, Mrs. Gertraud; we have been young too.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Aye, she is no more a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: The better for her if she thinks so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: She runs to her destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: For these few steps, where is the danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: One missstep is enough for a fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Here in the valley—

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Even here in the valley, Knight, have you then observed nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What should I observe?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: That young boy, the pious Pilgrim's Son.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: She is fond of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Aye, aye, mother, has she told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: H'm! Such things young damsels never tell. She may scarcely know it herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And how do you know it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Miss Elsbeth has forgot sitting still, she is for ever walking out.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Well, but is that all.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P:
To the North is a beautiful wood,—that is not her
rout; to the South is a pleasant declivity reaching to the very lake—that does not attract her—westward a charming eminence, where the great poplar tree stands, there she finds no pleasure either—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Well, and whither walks she then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Constantly to the East, where the rock is rough∣est, and at every step the neck is in danger; always to this valley where the shoes at every step stick in the mud, and the sun at the meridian scarcely drys the dew.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: H'm! h'm!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Henry is her first word at rising in the morning and her last at bed time.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: h'm! h'm!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: If I prepare a delicious soup or you have brought home some fine game, she never forgets, that Henry should have a bit of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: H'm! h'm!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Of the fine wine, your brother Abbot sent you lately from Italy, she immediately hid a bottle behind her bed.—For whom, Lady?—she would not tell—but for whom else but Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Aye, aye, this, to be sure, looks strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: A Nosegay from him, common as the flowers may be, she never takes off her bosom till it is entirely de∣cayed.—The roguish boy carves her name on every tree—yes, all must come out—this morning the naughty children have—I am ashamed, to tell—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What have they done then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: They have—I tremble thinking of it?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Quick, quick, out with it!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.STAGE: (With a deep sigh, making the sign of a cross before her)
SP.P: they have kissed each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Kissed? aye, aye, that's too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: If Walter of Blonay were to hear of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Yes, Mrs. Gertraud, he would quit the connex∣ion, and that of right.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: My advice would be to lock her up in her chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: The needle in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And the spinning-wheel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And a holy legend.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And a prayer book.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What is the boy about, he is not of noble birth. Not long since I wished to take him as a page, for I liked his bold and fine appearance. I thought his father to be a disguised knight, driven by ill fate into this wilderness. A christian action it would have been, to give the boy, for God's sake, a noble education. But when I sounded the father about his birth and rank, I soon discovered him to be of low descent, with not a single helmet in his coat of arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Henry is however, a good boy, I can't deny that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: May be, Mrs. Gertraud, but he must let the girl alone. I'll speak to brother Peter a few words; he is prudent and pious, he will find advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Here comes the old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Then leave us to ourselves, and see where Els∣beth is, loose her not out of sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Yes, yes, my eyes are well; but what of that, my bones will not carry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: God bless you, pious man.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I thank you noble knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I have a friendly word to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You have a lively boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: He is ripening to manhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Yes, I well observe that.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: He feels himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: A little too soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: He runs after my Elsbeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: You jest, knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Knighthood's honor and women's management, are things of which Cuno of Hallwyl does not make a jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: What gives you reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: H'm! Many things have happened—they love to be together.—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: They trifle, they play.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Like children.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: But they kiss each other!—Is that children's play?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And consequently—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Are you assured of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Mother Gertraud has seen it with her own eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No harm in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cruno.
SP.P: No harm? no harm? pious brother! you have grown so old and know not yet what a kiss means? If you have been chaste and modest all the days of your life, the better for you! but do'nt take it amiss, methinks the boy is not following your steps.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I thought, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Cruno.
SP.P: Be so good as to listen to what I mean. I think when straw and fire is put together, it creates a flame—Pray send the boy off to Italy, the sooner the better,—war is there, he may serve the Milanese as a foot soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My Henry a foot soldier!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And why not? he is not a nobleman? Better there to wound the enemy than here a father, who, without his dauthter, has neither treasure nor joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Be composed, noble knight, my Henry shall never wound you; this very day we quit this valley for∣ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: No, no, it was not meant so.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: We follow our des∣tiny.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Indeed! pious brother, you give unwelcome news—Your presence has brought blessing on my house—Re∣luctantly I let you go—What is it that drives you so sud∣denly from this peaceful valley? Has any of my subjects given you offence? Woe to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P:
No, noble knight, the palm of peace has over∣shawdowed eighteen years my quiet hut, thanks to you for it: my wants you helpfully supplied—Never shall I
forget it. When dire disease laid my wife upon the sick bed, your kitchen and cellar were open; you yourself were day and night at her bed side; your tears dropped upon her sick bed—and at last upon her grave—that is engraven upon my heart!—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You move me, brother; you know I am not rich myself, and would have willingly done more.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: The more generous of you. A bit of bread and heartfelt joy, are benefactions, which the rich seek in vain in their silver chests. It shall, by God, not re∣main unrewarded to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You have often rewarded me, by good advice and pious prayers. (feelingly) Stay with me, brother Peter! we are both old, why will you leave me? an old tree never takes root in foreign soil. Old men should not be separated, they do not so easily attach themselves to what is new. If you are not pleased any longer here in the valley? move up to the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I cannot, I must be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Have you persecuting enemies? In the castle you are secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My Agnez's grave chains me more to this soli∣tude than your prayers. But I cannot stay; love and duty—soon, noble knight, you shall learn what alone was able to draw me back to the world's tumult.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Then God be with you! you are a prudent ex∣perienced man, you best know what is fit for you. When will you depart?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: This very hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: So soon? I wish to furnish you first with vict∣uals for the journey. I have this morning killed a sine deer, we will get it roasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Thanks! we want but little.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Father, the sun shine so bright to day, the fish won't touch the hook. Blessing to you, noble knight! Is Miss Elsbeth with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: May be.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Where? where?—There father take the fish and let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Stay. I have to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Are you in haste?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: () Speak then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I will not interrupt you. Adieu, pious brother. You will, I hope not leave this abode without a farewell draught?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Each moment of delay would be treason to my country.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Then go, and may God be with you. I am sor∣ry. In distant regions, forget me not in your prayers.—Farewell!—No, we part not yet. I'll go for Elsbeth, and then pass this way again.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What is he muttering about? Parting! A fare∣well draught.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: We must go.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What does that mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Your wishes are fulfiled.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Which?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: You was desirous of going into the wide world.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: And that shall be?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: This very day.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You are jesting, father?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I speak in earnest. The strange pilgrim has brought me intelligence—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Inform me of its purport?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My country is distracted—it wants my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Your country?—I am ashamed to ask; where is your country?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Where we are going.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: (whose uneasiness encreases) Indeed?—but who meanwhile will mind our houshold?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henceforth we want it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The hut will fall to pieces, the garden decay—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Even so?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Better for me to stay and keep every thing in order.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: How? would you let me go alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I am so young your country would have no confidence in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: But I—I need a valiant youth, who, standing by my side, will learn of me to fight, conquer—and to die—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: To die?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: And why not? man is born to learn, and dies to learn. In death the feeblest old man triumphs over the strongest youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You shall not fall, (pointing to his breast) here is your shield.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Right, my son! you see I cannot do without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well then!—I must accompany you—but when shall we return?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Never! What do you mean? The fight can∣not last forever. We will combat bravely till winter comes, then return and enjoy tranquility under our straw roof.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henry, what's that? I understand you not—Not farther back than this morning each hour seemed to oppress you; even this morning you desired impetuously to travel into the world; and now at my meeting you half way, you deem your obedience a sacrifice?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Father, I know it not myself—I am in a sad disposition—I conceive it not—you are a prudent man, explain it me? why the world sometimes seems to me to be too narrow, and then again I would not change yonder hut for the emperor's throne of Trapezunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Habit—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Be it what it will, you must promise me a spee∣dy return, or I shall grieve to death!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I can promise you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You are my good father—I would willingly obey you—indeed with all my heart—but—I must confess—Miss Elsbeth is so dear to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: What is Elsbeth to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A great deal. She has, I know not how, stolen into my heart—wherever I am, she is with me; where∣ver I go she hovers before me. In the wood she stands be∣hind every tree, and in the hut her rays appear from eve∣ry corner. If I lay down, she sits before me; when I awake she still sits there.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Separation will cure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Yes, if I was but gone! but—be not angry, Father—I cannot go!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henry, if I tell you, that a person is yet alive, to whom nature has given stronger pretensions to your heart, than to this damsel?—If I tell you that you still have a mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I a mother? does not yonder hill cover her grave?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My Agnez has saved your life, but not given it you. She was your infancy's faithful nurse, yet she who brought you to this world lives still.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: She lives?—Who am I then?—Have you ever been married to her?—Disowned your wife, and took another?—or are you not my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: If love and care give a right to that title—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry
SP.P: Not otherwise?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Alas! you rob me of a father whom I love, and give me a mother whom I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Hasten to her arms!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I will not. I do not wish a strange mother!—I entreat you for God's sake! stay my father!—I have so long since accustomed myself to love you as a child, and I am now to deliver up my heart to strange hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: To a mother's hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: That sounds fine, but (pointing to his heart) this does not echo to it. Never have I known my mother; by what benefaction has she attached me to her? What pretension of hers can out balance yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: The rights of nature.

DIV3.P:
Nature, nature—I know not what that means. Have you then made an alliance with nature to win my heart? Can I love my mother more than you? More than Miss
Elsbeth?—In God's name, how came I to be an orphan all at once!—For pity's sake! stay father, or I throw my∣self into the stream!—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Be consoled, I shall remain your father, as long as you may acknowledge me for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: As long as I live! as long as a drop of blood—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Well then! a father may require obedience of his son. Prepare for your departure. Before sun-set we quit this valley.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Without taking leave of my Elsbeth?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: You have invested me with a father's rights. We have not to loose a moment. Soon you shall know why!

How am I?—all used to be serene about me—now all so dark—the rock seems to be higher—the valley nar∣rower—the high trees make too much shade—I am peevish—I must weep— (pauses) a mother?—what is that?—who can tell me what it is?—I have no sense for it—and what shall I do at her abode?—can she not come to me?—will she tear me from Miss Elsbeth?—that is not the way to my heart—no, no, no.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: Elsb.(Entering slowly, with a garland in her hand, takes suddenly the hat from Henry's head, placing the garland upon it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ah Elsbeth! dear Elsbeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do I look like a boy

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You jest and I am half dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You? let us see, how one looks, when one is half dead? red cheeks—clear eyes—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Full of tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Tears?—Indeed, I perceive one, Henry, are you unwell?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Would to God—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Fy, what a wish!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Bad enough. Yes, would to God I were ill! then my father would be obliged to leave me behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What are you talking about?—Quick! be∣fore my father and Gertraud overtake me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I—ah, Elsbeth! (he takes the garland from his head) this will become my funeral garland!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: For God's sake! torment me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I must go!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Where to?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Into the wide world!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: To fight—to kill men—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What have they done to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: To me?—nothing at all—They might all live for me to the day of judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well then let them live and stay here.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: But you will soon return, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: That's the very thing—I shall not return—Eslbeth! I shall never see you again!—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Never see me again—then I shall not see you again either?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ah? that breaks my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Dear Henry! you alarm me—weep not— (she drys his tears with her apron) Look at me—speak rea∣son—who desires it then, that you never shall see me again?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My father, and yet not my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Are you raving?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: He just now left me—just now he discovered to me, that I am not his son.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: God forbid! Henry, a father certainly you will have!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: It's all the same to me. If this is not my father, I won't have another.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Why not? There are more good fathers in the world. For instance my father—if he would take you for my brother—how funny it would be.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: H'm! would not be very funny. A sister one dares not marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Will you then really marry me?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Indeed! I love you above all—more than you love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: That's not true,

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: It's true enough. See, my eyes are full of tears—my heart is filled with grief—and you remain in good humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I think, Henry, if you love me so much—so very much; you would soon return—is it not so, Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If I dare.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Who will prevent you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Who is your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: How do I know! it is a mother whom I never saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: But certainly a good women, if she is your mother. Be composed, Henry, there is my hand, I will become your wife and no other's.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do you promise that?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: How shall I swear?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: By your Patroness.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Well, I swear by the holy Agatha!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You will not marry Walter of Blonay?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You will wait for news of poor Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Most certainly!—Be now friendly again.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ah! It's all very fine and good; but how can I. be friendly? We are to part—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: When?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: This very day, before sun-set, we leave this valley, so says my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: What is that: Parting? How shall we do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P:
You give me your hand—I shake it heartily—you look at me sorrowfully—I weep—you say farewell—
and I say farewell—then one goes this and the other that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Ah, Henry! that's hard!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Very hard!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Stay with me!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Aye! and you beg too—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Stay with me!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Yes, if you move me so— (hastily resolved) Elsbeth! I'll stay with you!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Father, I cannot go with you! Elsbeth loves me—she begs—she weeps—I am distract∣ed—and—in short—I cannot go with you!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Then I shall tell your mother that she has borne an undutiful child.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Say what you please. Whoever bears this saint at his heart is not without affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: And your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why did she throw me from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: But, if till now she thinks you dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Then leave her in that opinion. Long since she has done grieving for that loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: How? you would not give joy to her that gave you life? The bird in his nest fondly flutters to its mo∣ther—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Because she has a worm in her bill for its nourishment. But what has my mother done for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: She has suffered for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Anxiety, love, hope, desire, is true life! All that is given to me by Elsbeth, she alone is my mother! therefore I'll stay with her, exchange love for love, will hope as a boy, desire as a youth, and combat for the pos∣session of her, like a man!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: If your heart overcomes your reason, remem∣ber at least a father's right, which you have voluntarily conferred on me. You must go with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You say, you must!—Elsbeth says nothing—she only looks at me—and I can only obey her.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Miss, I claim my son from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Will you bring him back again to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I can promise nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Go alone! Tell his mother to come here, and she will find a son and daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A precious thought! Yes father! go alone!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Your Henry shall mean while want for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Remember me to my mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And return soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I am troublesome to you, it seems. Well Miss! If your father has no objection.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My father is a good pious Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Here he comes. Ask him yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Did I not say so? on our left she vanished be∣hind a bush, and on our right hand we find her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Aye! aye!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Father, the pious brother Peter will leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: So I hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: But Henry must stay, say?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: He stay here? and why?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Because I love him so much—almost as much as I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And she says that with as little reserve as if she was repeating a rosary. Naughty child!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno,
SP.P: Elsbeth, have you renounced all female modesty?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: How so, father?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You must love but your bridegroom, Walter of Blonay; and even to him you must not discover it so bluntly.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: He certainly will not hear of it by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno
SP.P: Henry goes with his father, and you stay at home in your chamber till you are conducted to the marriage altar.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do you hear, Elsbeth?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Grieve not; remember my promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Oh, noble knight! keep me at your castle as the meanest servant: I will mind your horses and feed your dogs. Dear mother Gertraud, pray speak a good word for me. I will catch birds for your old cat, and tap you on your back when you are coughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: My old cat will have enough to eat without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Go with your father, Henry, that's becoming a son. Here is no abode for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Enough, children, my hours are counted: we must part.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Part?—hear you, Elsbeth?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I will hear nothing—I will not part.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You must—Farewell, brother Peter! It goes to my heart to lose you, but who knows to what it may lead. This thoughtless damsel gives me trouble.—Travel under God's protection! and remember me in your prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: As often as I shall meet a noble hearted man, I shall remember you. Farewell! (they shake hands) allow the children a last farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Now make haste! shake hands!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Then we must part indeed, Elsbeth! Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: (Also weeping) Forget me not!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Remember your oath!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: By the holy Agatha!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: When you ramble here, speak to me as if I was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Be always brave and love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: There in the garden is a rose-bush, I have plan∣ted it for you, water it sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: With my tears—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My pigeons I give you, feed them.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Out of my mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: The poor children move my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Away Elsbeth! 'tis enough!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: God's blessing on the journey!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: May the saints attend you wherever you go?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Go, go, my heart breaks!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Farewell, Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.STAGE: (Without looking back, with a faultering voice)
SP.P: Farewell, Elsbeth. (Cuno, Gertraud and Elsbeth, are out of sight.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Compose yourself, son, be a man!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If a man dare not weep, I will not be a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsh.
SP.P: Henry! dear Henry! Forget me not!The name of that floweret in the German language, is Forget me not. (she gives him the floweret and goes away.)

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: (Drying his tears and looking at the flower) H'm!—What does this flower avail? to-marrow it will be wither'd. (He puts it on his hat) Had she given me a handkerchief or a ribbon, I would have revered it more than the relics of the convent of Einsiedeln, I would have tied it round my arm, or pinned it to my helmet, and then away into the throngest ranks of the enemy. Hah, fa∣ther! If we are not to remain among friends, I wish we were already amidst the tumult of our foes.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Well then, my son, take your walking stick! the sun is lowering in the west, the birds sing their even∣ing songs, it is high time.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If we had but the Alps in our rear; if but the castle was not so high, as to remain so long in view.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Look forwards. Patience Henry! When time and separation are united, they extinguish flaming letters in the hearts of men.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Never, father! Lead me to the holy sepulchre; tell me: on this stone sat the prophesying angel, and there my eyes will behold Elsbeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Great events await you

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Great events shall meet with a man in me, if Elsbeth is the price.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: The path from this wildesness leads perhaps to a throne.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P:
You jest. And do we sit easier upon a throne than here under this appletree? What think you father? If with your left hand you could take hold of a sceptre,
and with your right draw the good Agnez from the grave, which would you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Your youthful passion is like Aurora's feeble beam; but matrimonial bliss is like the glowing bright∣ness of the meridian sun.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Good! My meridian will also in its course arrive. Elsbeth or no other!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Deserve her.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Lead me to the battle! glory or death!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: BRUNO, with a bundle on his back—The FORMER.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: We are ready to depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Messenger of woe!

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: I a messenger of woe,? hah, if you knew—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Rally not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: In this bundle I carry for you a knightly armor.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: For me? What means that? who am I? speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: That leads us too far. Patience my son, 'till evening at the first inn you shall know your fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: One question more you will grant me, before we leave this valley: Does my birth favor my union with Elsbeth?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: How miserable am I! Why has not one of my ancestors met with a girl like Elsbeth! Love would have made him a knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Honor's open arms await you, let us hasten!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ah!
SP.STAGE: (They go a few steps. Peter stands still and stretches his arms out towards the hut.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P:
How?—Shall I then turn my back to you little hut, which for eighteen years has given me a friend∣ly shelter?—Is not one wet eye of gratitude to be cast on you?—Fy on the man who suffers shipwreck, and can without feeling burn the piece of board, upon which he safely reached the shore. How many serene moments have
love, hope, and piety created for me here!—May lightening and storm spare your rotten roof! and give shelter to many a weary pilgrim! May the doves contin∣ue to coo on the tops of these cedar trees, and fetch their food from this garden, where henceforth no one will dis∣trub them. (he turns round and looks at the distant hill) But ah! whose hand will nurse the plants which orna∣ment my Agnez's grave?—Agnez!—to seperate myself from your dust!— (rashly) go, Bruno, follow him, Henry—one moment more for my heart! Then I belong to you and our country.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Well, let us then in God's name begin our journey!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: There it is! Lead in my feet. Give me a push in my back, to make me tumble forwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.STAGE: (Takes out a sword from under his cloth)
SP.P: This sword is for you, Baron!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: For me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Let me carry it, it might hinder you in walk∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Old boy! if you are fatigued, I'll take you yourself on my back. Hah! Elsbeth! I have a sword.
SP.STAGE: (He goes off rashly, Bruno follows him.)

(Peter for so me time looks at the hut feelingly, then at the ap∣ple tree, from which he takes a twig and puts it on his hat; then he goes to the hole, and looks earnestly down; he then turns towards the distant grave, towards which he at last stretches out his hands, and sinks upon his knees. After a short and silent prayer, he rises. goes off slowly; looks often back, and at last gets out of sight behind the trees.)

P.HI: An open place at ARLES surrounded with trees; in the back ground the palace of the Count of Burgundy. In the foreground the house of a Cooper who with his journeyman, is occupied at his door, in putting hoops to a barrel. They often stop working, to talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: YOU have travelled through the world, Nicholas, where did you like it best?

SP.SPEAKER: Nicholas.
SP.P: Arles is my native place, and at home a drink of water relishes better, than on foreign soil, the best of wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: Thank God! we may now on Sunday drink again a glass of wine together.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: You have been but badly off for some time back.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: Ah! Nicholas, God meant it well with you, that he did not bring you sooner back to your home. All was upside down here.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: I was but a boy, when the wicked Count Ulrich killed our pious Count Albrecht.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: Brother-slaughter! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: And yet the murderer died quietly on his bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: On his bed he died, it's true, but quiet? (he shakes his head.) He could not even dose quietly. A prince who goes to bed without a good action, goes without consolation to his grave. At the first knock of my hammer in the morning, suddenly there came a guard from the palace: Mr. Benedict, the Count orders you to leave off hammering! it disturbs his morning slumber. H'm! I murmured to myself: can he also defend the hammering of his conscience?—

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: It's a wonder he did'nt drive you from your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: This almost happened once—"Your hut," he said, disfigures the place before the palace;"—My lord, I answered: Integrity and industry are the occupants of this hut; would to God! we could say that of many a pal∣ace"—" I will buy your hut," continued he—"I will not sell it. My great, great, grandfather has built it, my father repaired it, I was born and educated in it. My old father is blind and can find his way in it without dan∣ger. But if I bring him to a strange house he will knock out his brains."—What answer do you think my lord deigned to give me?—"Well then", he said, stroking his beard; and what of that?"—

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: The tyrant!

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: In short, my house would have been gone, if Block the cabinet-maker had not been on friendly terms with the court jester—he brought things in order.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: There was Count Albrecht, God grant him a happy resurrection! quite a different man.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: Indeed he was! always friendly and good. Here he often would stop to look at my work, and when the sun was burning, he would never suffer me to take off my hat. Many a time he drank out of my silver cup.—I still see him passing by here, his little sons hopping round him. Oh! the dear little ones! they would take off their caps before every mechanic—nod to every fruit woman—and if they met a beggar, how quick they would put their little hands in their pockets, and filled, with silver pieces, hold them to the poor.—Oh! It goes to my very heart, when I think, how unmercifully they all were sent to the grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: None escaped?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: No, not one. I myself heard in that woful night the groans of the dying—the lamentations of the Count's attendants—the piercing cries of the mother proceeding from the palace windows.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: The old Countess lives still?

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P:
It would be better for her, if she was dead. To spare her was worse than murder. The good Lady buried herself in a Convent. She may have forgot hus∣band and children, but the splendor of high life, and the
thirst for revenge, she cannot forget, it is said.—It's na∣tural, she was mother—I am only a burgher, but could I find one of the murderers, I would hammer him into a hoop.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: Count Ulrich's son, they say, promises well?

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: He is but a boy. A thorn-bush never bears plumbs. As long as Count Hugo of Werdenberg, the governor, guides his youth—that's a worthy knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: See there, master, what an uproar at the city gates?—

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: What's that to us? a drunken man perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: I see halberds fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: No matter. It is no more than it was in former times, when even the most honest of us went out of the way of every page.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: The tumult encreases—they approach.

SP.SPEAKER: Bruno.
SP.P: Now? what can that be?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Some citizens run over the stage, calling: ring the alarm bell! the alarm bell! another croud of citizens, led by BLOCK, are push∣ing on.

SP.SPEAKER: Block.
SP.P: Here, citizens of Arles! here, to the palace∣yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Neighbour Block, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Block.
SP.P: Friend Benedict, leave your work! shocking things! the day of revenge is arrived!

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Revenge! Revenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Revenge? on whom? wherefore?

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Bring the murderers here! let them bleed under the palace windows!

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: What murderers?

SP.SPEAKER: Block.
SP.P: Pilgrims have been taken, the Count's sealing ring has been found upon them.—

SP.SPEAKER: Another.
SP.P: And the cup with the Burgundian arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Hah! Just heaven! The avenging angel con∣ducted them to Arles! Where are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Block.
SP.P: They have been carried to prison—

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Bring them forward! ring the alarm-bell!

STAGE.HI: (The alarm-bell is heard ringing. The tumult is encreas∣ing. They ask, they call, cry, relate, rave, all pell mell).

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Blessing on me, that I live to see this day! Do you see, Nicholas, how these men are still attached to their murdered lord? Thus benefactions shoot like flowers from the grave of the just, rise Count Albrecht's spirit! from your vault, and behold your blood's revenge glowing in the love of your people. (The gates of the palace open.)Some voices cry: the Governor! the go∣vernor!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Count HUGO of Werdenberg comes out of the palace, in the midst of the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
