SP.P: What is it, children? what has happened here?—
SP.STAGE: (The people are crowding round him, each eager to tell his story, nothing but a confused noise is heard.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: I understand you not. Speak singly.

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Speak, Mr. Martin! (All are silent.)

SP.SPEAKER: Martin,
SP.P: I was some days journey in the country about business. On my return, in a village a league from here night overtook me, and after having sent on my cattle, I laid down with other strangers upon the straw. It was dark. But when day light appeared, I awoke, and cast a glance upon the sleeping Strangers. An old man in Pilgrim's habit lay at my side. His cloth had been disordered. I saw an armour under his habit, which excited my curiosity. I looked at him attentively, and perceived on his finger a ring with a seal, exactly resem∣bling the ring of our murdered Count, which I often heard described, when it was missing.

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Count Albrecht's murderer! he is found! revenge! blood!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Silence! Silence! Let him continue speaking!

SP.SPEAKER: Martin.
SP.P:
My blood chilled. Yet I was uncertain till I discovered at the old man's feet, a large silver cup—they may have been drinking the evening before on their hap∣py
return—when I took up the cup, the arms of Burgun∣dy stared me in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Enough! Enough! bring him here!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Silence, brethren! Let your fellow citizen fi∣nish his account!

SP.SPEAKER: Martin.
SP.P: I was on the point of drawing my knife to send the villain to hell, when he opened his eyes. Beside him lay a fine youth, and another man in Pilgrim's habit. He roused them and they took their way towards the city. I kept them company, not to loose sight of them. On the way the old man asked me many questions; whether the people still loved the memory of their good old Count Albrecht? whether they hated his murderers? and some such things. He also spoke of you, Governor, and seemed to rejoice when he learnt that you were still living and in good health. At our arrival at the gates, I called the guards. We found in their travelling bag among other suspicious things, Swathing clothes, mark∣ed with the Burgundian arms, and the letter H, under a Lordly Crown. They certainly have once belonged to the poor little Count Henry, whose innocent blood the villain has spilt.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Revenge! Blood! Bring them here!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Citizens of Arles! You have suffered under an oppressive yoke. You know, what may be the evil consequence of a precipitate sentence. Be slow in pu∣nishing! examine carefully! the prisoners cannot es∣cape you. Hear them, and judge coolly that the smoke of innocent blood may not again rise from this ground.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: He is right!—Let us hear them—quick! quick!

SP.SPEAKER: A voice.
SP.P: Behold, the guards are already conducting the old man towards us!

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: This way, guards! this way to the blood tribunal!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: PETER, tied, and conducted by a GUARD, enters with a serene countenance, among the PEOPLE.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Place him in our centre.

SP.SPEAKER: A guard.
SP.P: He desired to be brought before the people.

SP.SPEAKER: A voice in the back ground.
SP.P: See whether he has an armour under his habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Some of the people
SP.STAGE: (Who are nearest to Peter, lift up his habit and cry out)
SP.P: Yes! yes!

SP.SPEAKER: One voice.
SP.P: Look for the ring at his finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Some
SP.P: Yes! yes!

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Cut him down! tear him to pieces! stone him to death!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Guards protect him! away with you! a few minutes only!—hear him! citizens of Arles! if you love me!—I en∣treat you the ashes of your murdered lord!
SP.STAGE: (The more reasonable citizens unite with Hugo and the guards.)
SP.P: Back! back! he has desired to speak to the people. Let us hear what the criminal has to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Silence! In the name of justice! let her bal∣ance the scales, and then strike with the sword. (All are silence. To Peter) You have heard what heavy crimes you are accused of.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: An ignominious death threatens the innocent in vain! tears of joy roll down my cheeks, and wet the chains which I carry with honor. After eighteen years elapse, I behold with extacy the love of the citizens still fervent for my good Count Albrecht. He was my friend, my benefactor! woe to his murderers!

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: His friend?—his benefac∣tor?—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Citizens of Arles! formerly my dear fellow citizens! is there not one among you, that recognizes me?
SP.STAGE: (All press forward to look at his face.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Nor you my brother in arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Indeed! this voice does not sound strange to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My God! have time and grief thus disfigured my features? Is there not one who in his native place bids welcome to Hans of Bonstetten?

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Hans of Bonstetten?—'Tis he!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Hans of Bonstetten my friend, and brother! has the grave vomited you again?—

SP.SPEAKER: A voice.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I remember him.

SP.SPEAKER: Another.
SP.P: And I too.

SP.SPEAKER: A third.
SP.P: A brave and good man.

SP.SPEAKER: A fourth.
SP.P: The bosom friend of our Court!

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Take off his chains! Let us carry him on our hands to the grave of our murdered lord.
SP.STAGE: (The guards take off his chains. He throws away the pilgrim's habit, and appears in the dress of a warlike knight.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Yes, to the grave of my good Albrecht! hasten, citizens of Arles! behold his only son, crown him as your lawful sovereign!

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: his son! his son!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Overcome your surprise! hear me! hear a friend's voice. In that dreadful night, when the clash∣ing of the swords of hired murderers, and the groans of the dying surrounded me; when my good master al∣ready lay bleeding at my feet, and his elder sons were drawing their last breath; I called my wife, to whose care the youngest child was entrusted: Agnez, I cried, save your precious nursling! the Count's ring I took from the finger of the corpse, the silver cup I snatched from the table. By a secret door we escaped and reached the open air. In the darkness of the night, through swamps and bushes, through thorns and thistles, we walked on unused roads. The sun rose but to perplex us, for he gave light to our pursuers. During day we hid ourselves in cornfields, and silenced our hunger with unripe corn, God guarded your prince! we reached the frontiers of Burgundy. Thence I sent my old companion, my faith∣ful servant Bruno, back. He was to wait in silence, till he could bring me news of better times. At the foot of the Alps, in a poor hermit's hut, I took care of the dear pledge, confided to me by God. The boy has ri∣pened to youthful beauty. Citizens of Arles! to day I brought him back to you! take him, and your future hap∣piness from my hands!

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Where—where!—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: He has been carried with me to prison. The hand that is to sway you, is in fetters.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Along! along! he lives! he lives! Al∣brech's son.
SP.STAGE: (The people run off huzzaing, the stage becomes suddenly empty.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Am I awake?—or in a dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Give me your hand, Hugo! we often parted on this spot squeezing each others hands, when we returned from the joyous feasts at the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Ah! what is become of those fine times!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: They will return. My Henry is a beautiful sprig of the old Burgundian stem. I educated him as a man, poor and low; blessing on the prince, who knows poverty!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Where is your good Agnez?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Do not obscure this hour to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: I understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Long live Count Henry of Burgundy!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Hah! they return already—Rejoice, Hugo, you will see a noble youth.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: The People carry HENRY upon their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: There he is! the young Count—an eye, like his father's!—his father's smiling countenance—Long live Count Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Some voices in the back ground.
SP.P: Let us see him too! we cannot behold him! lift him up!

SP.SPEAKER: Benedict.
SP.P: Put him here upon my barrel. (Henry is put upon the barrel. A loud huzza.) Long live Count Henry of Burgundy!
SP.STAGE: (Trumpets and kettle drums are heard from the castle.)

SP.SPEAKER: Some of the People.
SP.P: He weeps! He weeps!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P:
Your first sight of
me inspires you with love; for this I have to thank my father—May his blessing be upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Count Albrecht's blessing on his good son!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: If I cannot be to you, what he was,—I at least will love you as he did— (Lifting his hands and raising his eyes to heaven.) Give with me, thanks to God for my miraculous preservation.

SP.SPEAKER: All the People kneel down.
SP.P: We thank you, God!

SP.SPEAKER: A Woman's voice behind the scene.
SP.P: Where is he? where—where?

SP.SPEAKER: Some of the People.
SP.P: Hah! his mother!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess of BURGUNDY comes hastily upon the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: The People,
SP.P: Your son! your son! (pointing with their fingers to Henry.)

DIV3.STAGE: (She presses through the crowd, spies her Son, reaches out her arms towards him and sinks down speechless.)

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My Mother!

DIV3.STAGE: (He is going to jump down. The people gather round him, take him from the barrel and bring him to his mo∣ther's arms.)

SP.SPEAKER: The People.
SP.P: Long live Matilda! Long live Henry!

DIV3.STAGE: (Trumpets from the balcony of the Castle).

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: am I a mother yet?—is this my son?—the only one who was saved!— (she looks at him with complacency) oh! In this world we can forget all, but ma∣ternal love.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Give me your blessing!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: The blessing of your dear father be with you! a prince must be blessed by his people, not by his mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I will deserve the love of my people, and yours. By God! I will!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
Hah! my solitary cell will for the first time re-echo the maternal joy! no more shall I pray for re∣venge
before the Crucifix!—thanks!—thanks!—Oh how much a mother loves to speak these words to the Father of us all!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Gracious Countess, allow an old faithful ser∣vant to kiss the border of your garment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Knight Hans of Bonstetten! oh, will it ever be in my power to reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Woe to my heart, if such a scene did not re∣ward it!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: When for the last time you bid me good night in yonder hall—who could have thought, that the dawn of morning would be eighteen years after!—Where is your good Agnez?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Her morning has not yet dawned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I conceive,—you and I have but one son now.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Count Henry of Burgundy, deign me to be the first who swears allegiance to his new master.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Do not make me blush. Do not deprive me of the sweet name, which my heart cannot renounce! Call me your son! Be not ashamed of me before the people's face.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My son!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: People of Burgundy! If I once fulfil your hopes, if I succeed, in indemnifying you for the loss of my father, you will thank this man for it! He took nothing with him into the wilderness but what no tyrant could deprive him of—his virtues! I loved him when a child, I admired him when a youth, I shall imitate him when a man. He is not the first after me, he is the first above me! Whatever good through me may flow to you, are but the unfolded germs of his plantation. Could I ever forget, what he was to me—what he is—and will remain; then may God forget me forever!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: It is but a trifling merit, to raise good fruits from noble germs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Son! what I see and hear of you, makes me proud to be your mother.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: A crowd of people come tumultuously from the Palace, carrying a boy, bound.

SP.SPEAKER: The people.
SP.P: Revenge! bloody revenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: The Boy.
SP.P: Oh mercy! they have tied me.

SP.SPEAKER: Count Hugo,
SP.P: Who dares to tie this innocent boy?—I hope, Count, you will not tarnish the first hours of your reign with a cruelty? This boy is Ulrich's son, your cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: Boy,
SP.P: Welcome, cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: His father has murdered yours. But the son is not to expiate the father's crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Kill me not! I will love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Is he of that race?—hah! how the sight of him recalls all the terrors of past times! how it opens the graves that are overgrown with grass, how murdered corpses begin again to bleed!—Away with him from my sight, lest grief might tempt me to unnoble revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: What is she angry at?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: This pious hypocri∣tical look you inherited from your father; this deceitful smile you stole from your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Father and mother are dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Who could hate this fine boy? untie him.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I thank you, it was so painful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Be careful, son! do not nourish a serpent in your bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I am a good boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Your brothers blood calls for revenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Revenge for the living! Tears for the dead. If blood could open their graves, mine should flow.—Come here to me, my boy! what's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: My name is Guido.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Will you be my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Willingly. What's your name, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Then you are my brother Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Yes, I promise it to you in the face of God and my people!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Right, my son!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: May you never repent it!

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Be no more angry. I am afraid of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Leave me! time only can reconcile me to your sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Tell me, brother Henry, what have I done to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Be always good, and you will win her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Yes, I'll be always good. (He draws him aside.) What do you think, shall I give her this rosary?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: My brave boy!
SP.STAGE: [He lifts him up and presses him to his heart.]
[The People give signs of their emotions.]

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henry, I am contented with you; you have learnt to govern yourself; now, and not till now, you de∣serve to govern men.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Not yet, father; I have done but what my heart commanded.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.STAGE: [Who during this was in conversation with some old citizens, goes to Henry.]
SP.P: Noble Count, the citizens of Arles are desirous to welcome you according to old custom. They are going to bring you present, as many centuries ago the most respectable of the citizens brought to their first good prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Their approbation, their tears, were they not the most exquisite presents?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Never deny your people, what may give them pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Go children, and do, what can give you plea∣sure.

SP.SPEAKER: The Peop.
SP.P: Away, to the town-house! the presents! the old custom!

DIV3.STAGE: Hugo.[Conducts the boy to the palace.]

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Are you coming with us, brother Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I shall soon follow you, my dear boy.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: Matilda.(Standing with folded hands in deep medita∣tion.)

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What makes my good mo∣ther so thoughtful?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I?—Nothing!—All my senses are chained by the lovely dream.—I could not pray even—unless our Maker would accept these tears as an offering of thanks!—I am not ill, yet so faint—so fatigued—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Permit me to conduct you to your former re∣sidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Not there! my son! not yet!—From those gates the murderers have drawn your mother by her hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do not draw the past from its obscurity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Do you see that open window?—Ah! there in yonder hall!—

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: There, Countess, you were betrothed to the noble Albrecht.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: There have I seen my children's blood foaming against the walls!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I entreat you, mother—a veil over those images.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: No, not there!—Leave me my son!—Even pleasure wants respite. Allow me to take breath!—
SP.STAGE: (She sinks upon a bench at the gates of the palace.)

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Stay, my son. There are moments, in which even love becomes oppressive. Let me ask you: how do you feel?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well, my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: To have the people's happiness at ones heart, is great and noble! Is it not my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The heart of man is too narrow for such a sensation.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: It is that narrowness of heart, that makes a man think himself of superior quality to whom millions look up.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: It is the gratitude of millions only that can justify such a thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I told you, you would forget your youthful whims. Have I been in the right?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: No, my father, you have been a bad prophet.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: How?—Still the same—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Now and ever! now more than ever! The youthful dream has been realized by a miracle. My hopes were foolish; heaven has taken pity of my folly! I wear to day another coat, my heart beats under it the same as before; you call me Count of Burgundy, and I feel still that I am poor Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Is the sweet feeling, to render men happy, in∣divissible? Does it not gain higher attraction, by sharing it? Dare a Prince not to be a father? Must he not be a father; to learn in a small circle what he is to execute in a great one?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: He dares and must.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A prince, who is husband and father—was not this your own remark of yesterday?—has a tender feeling for the welfare of his subjects; he will not tear from a wife her husband, nor deprive a mother of her son, to carry him into war, which is perhaps excited by whim or ambition. But a prince who invites peace with forbear∣ance, will be presented by his princess with a garland, to ornament the welcome guest.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Right, my son! have I then desired of you, to remain unmarried?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Then let us send messengers to Hallwyl.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Why to Hallwyl!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I have given my word: Elsbeth or none!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: What Henry promised—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Count of Burgundy will perform!

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: It becomes you not.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: It becomes me not—a wicked word! Bad actions are as unbecoming the prince as the beggar. But to crown beauty and virtue, methinks is princely.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Youth! You have till now seen but few dam∣sels, and love in Elsbeth, but the sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P:
Well, then invite to court all the daughters of the country; I will look at them all as at a bed of flowers:
here a beautiful tulip; there an odoriferous violet: here an innocent lilly; there a scented pink—Oh! they are all nothing in comparison to the queen of flow∣ers, the glowing rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Indeed, Henry, you have a turn for poetry. But learn first your people's wish, your mother's council; follow the one, and obey the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do not deny my first re∣quest!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Rise, my son, what is your wish?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You bestowed your blessing on your son—ah! you have a daughter too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: In the Swiss mountains there dwells a valiant knight, his family is noble and renowned; but the most noble of her sex is Elsbeth of Hallwyl—my beloved—let me add: my wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Do I hear right? you are married?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Not without your blessing. Speak a friendly word, and I fly to the arms of my graceful bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Rise, my son. What answer can I give you? you are of age.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: My Henry knows that a son in his mother's presence, never is of age.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I know it, and wait my judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A Baroness Hallwyl you mentioned?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: This name comprises all that is good and beau∣tiful!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: You know her, Bonstetten?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: I know her. She wants nothing but equal birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A nobler creature was never born.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Count of Burgundy! the hearts of princes are subject to the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: To choose another consort, were depriving my people of a mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: You must support your throne by brilliant allian∣ces.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Even without splendor, virtue is a powerful support.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: The rich heiress of Savoy—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do not finish the sentence, mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: She would bring you a principality as a dowry.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Without Elsbeth, I will even renounce what I possess already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: She is handsome and good.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Here is no space left for any other beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Examine first your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A heart that remained firm in the intoxication of fortune, wants no other proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Wait a year at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I dare not delay, another sues for her possession. Ah! if it already was too late!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: You destroy my dearest wishes, deprive me of high views.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A purple coatA dress wore by the European princes when sitting in state. is not the garment of domestic happiness; a heart without love remains cold even under a furr coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Knight of Bonstetten, tell me in sincerity, what you think of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Shall I speak as a man or as a courtier?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Speak as a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Well then! I have seen these young plants en∣twine their roots I am not able to separate them.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Thanks! thanks! for this paternal word.—Oh! my mother! what means your serious silence?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Indeed, eighteen years of soli∣tude have taught me to distinguish truth. I know the tears of anxiety and love.—Ah! I know them!—You have sub∣dued my pride, go and obey the wishes of your heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.STAGE: (In extacy, embraces alternately Peter and his mother.)
SP.P: Father!—Mother!—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: It's well you come, dear Count; you have gained my confidence—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Too soon, my noble young master! confidence is not a piece of coin, to put upon the hazard of a die; we must not gain, but deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The opportunity is at hand. I employ you as my suitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: For your future spouse?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Count Hugo, you are a Courtier. If I am to confide in you, I must travel with you myself. I myself!—excellent!—a numerous suite accompa∣nies the ambassador of Burgundy, myself amongst them as a page; hide myself behind his attendants; to be wit∣ness of Elsbeth's charming bashfulness;—hear her re∣fuse the Count of Burgundy for Henry's sake! hear how the prince in vain endeavours to dispossess the poor her∣mit's son from her heart.—All this I shall see and hear, run to her arms and with a kiss—snatch the approach∣ing terror from her lips!—happy Henry! you will ra∣diate above all the sons of princes! for, which of them can say: The girl loved me, and not my purple!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Still I am at a loss—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You shall know all—and when shall we set off?—to-morrow early—no, the days are hot—in the cool of the evening—or—at this moment—the sun is setting.

SP.SPEAKER: Peter.
SP.P: Henry, it is yet but noon. Devote this day at least to your people.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The most solemn day for them is yet to come! that day when I with Elsbeth at my side will enter the gates of Arles, when old and young stare at us with admiration; when the children will smilingly stretch out their little hands, while they fancy they behold an angel; and old men with emotion exclaim: Now we may die contented—O mother! mother!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV3.STAGE: A solemn march. Boys and girls dressed in white, lead in the midst of them, a lamb, ornamented with ribbons. They are followed by youths and young girls with garlands. Some old men close the procession, one of whom carries a golden cup filed with pieces of gold. The procession ranges itself on both sides. The music is silent. The old man with the cup advances, and addresses HENRY.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Man.
SP.P: My hands tremble; but of pleasure; my eyes are wet; but with tears of joy!—Accept, noble Count, according to immemorial custom, the trifling pre∣sents of our city, It is an old custom. I beg you to consider: that love to our princes is also an old custom.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Your love is my paternal in∣heritance. What I have not to acquire, I shall at least know how to preserve.

SP.SPEAKER: A young Damsel,
SP.STAGE: (approaches him and puts a myr∣tle garland on his head).
SP.P: Father of our country, give us soon a mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I thank you, my child. Before these myrtles decay, your wishes shall be fulfilled.

SP.SPEAKER: A little Girl,
SP.P: Noble Count, take this lamb, the emblem of our innocence. It can yet but leap and play; but under your care it will grow, and give milk and wool.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.STAGE: (gives the lamb to a page, embraces the little girl, and throws the pieces of gold into her apron).
SP.P: Take this, and carry it to your parents.

SP.SPEAKER: Little Girl.
SP.P: I am an orphan.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry,
SP.P: Then I give you a mother!—attendants give me some wine! the cup is empty! the presents of my people, are flown back to them. Your love is the only present I preserve in my bosom; you have exchanged your hearts for mine. (A page has meanwhile filled the cup.) Long live my peo∣ple! (He drinks.)

SP.SPEAKER: The old man.
SP.P: Blessing on our fine young lord!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Prosperity! and blessing!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.
DIV2.P: An Apartment in the Castle of Hallwyl.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: ELSBETH—Alone. (She is spining. Beside her hangs a cage with a bird in it.)

SP.P: ARE you tired at last with singing, little warbler? What makes you pick so much at the wire? you want to get out?—Will you desert me too, you only crea∣ture, to whom I may complain of what oppresses me!—Tarry only, till Henry returns—Oh! he'll come for certain!— (She spins, and tries to sing) God knows, why I cannot sing;—my throat is not sore, but strangled.—Formerly when I was leaping down the mountain, I sang louder than you, dear Lin∣net! that Henry might know me at a distance. Now every thing is so silent about me, that I can hear the moving of the time-piece at the wall.—It perhaps points to my last hour!—Well then!—If Henry not returns— (she spins and weeps.) Of this flax they shall weave my shroud; it is wetted with my tears!—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Mother GERTRAUD, with a large bunch of flowers.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Be joyful, Miss! all troubles are at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: (Jumping up) Is Henry here?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What! Henry! he may go on a pilgrimage to Palestine, and fetch a splinter of the holy cross, a good remedy for the toothach. No, quite different things are now in question! Behold this beautiful nosegay, varie∣gated like a wood-pecker, odorifarous like Indian spice. Whom do you think I got it of.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Its indifferent to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Do but see, and smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My rose is finer and smells more delicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: The withered rose? hah! hah! hah! you have not taken it from your bosom these ten days.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: But I plucked it from the bush which Henry planted.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: And what of that? you will soon sing another song. Hurrah! Miss, your bridegroom is arrived.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: No, no, he does not come so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: He is even now in the armory, in conversation with your father. He sent me, meanwhile, with this nosegay.—give my love, he said, to the noble young lady, my charming bride. And then he slipped a piece of gold into my hand, the dear gentleman!—Your father sends you word to dress yourself in your best clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My good mother, plague me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Plague you, indeed! poor child, ha! ha! ha! she is ashamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Is the knight here indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Indeed he is; why should I cause you useless joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And is come, to take me for a wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What else for then?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: No! never!
SP.STAGE: (She leans against an open window and looks sorrowfully through it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P:
I don't know what to think of you. I am afraid the old witch down in the village has played her tricks with you. That wicked hag does great mischief among men and cattle. The magistrates should be more vigilant. Is it not a pity, how the poor child pines away. Her clothes become too wide. She used to hop along upon one leg, but now she can scarcely crawl upon two. For∣merly she laughed at every thing; now she weeps for no∣thing. But patience, she will laugh enough, when she sees this fine knight. He is grown thick and sat; a dark complexion, black wiskers, a fine dress, and feathers in his hat. All is alive below in the castle yard; there are pages and chamber maids, horses and mules, chests and trunks without number. Ah! what fine things and bridal ornaments must they contain. My mouth water at the
thought of it!—Heaven has at last granted my prayers, I shall live to conduct my sweet young lady to her bridal chamber, and put on her nightcap.—But, you hear me not, what are you staring at through this window?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do you see, dear Gertraud, Henry's hut below in the valley?—Alas, it is empty!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: What do you care about the old rotten hut, think rather of Walter's stately castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: A hut with Henry!—Ah! but a hut with Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Pshaw! dear child, better is better! Love's easi∣est death, ir the death of hunger.—But, what are you about? the bird will fly out.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: So he shall. (She opened the cage.) Go and seek thy mate.

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Strange girl! She has fed and nursed that little bird with the greatest care—and now the whim takes her—hush! they are coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: In the name of God!

SP.SPEAKER: Gertr.
SP.P: Where, where are you going to?—Yet, she is in the right! she has to put on her Sunday clothes. Bertha shall curl her hair. A gown with a long sweeping train—a hoop petticoat—a gold chain—and then no meat for Henry, though he were Emperor Henry, the bird catcher. (She waddles off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: If I only do not appear too old to the beautiful Elsbeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Too old? how mean you that?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I am passed the years, in which men sing love∣songs to women, and dress themselves in their colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: My Elsbeth has no colours. A blank shield without device.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P:
I was but a youth, when by my bravery in bat∣tle, I acquired the crowned Lyon for my device. Many
a fine damsel would then have rejoiced, if I had exchang∣ed the lion, crown and all, for a heart pierced by darts. But now—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Well? now? Are you not still a manly, active knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I don't know. My journey to the holy Sepul∣chre has hurt my constitution, the Egyptian sun has brought wrinkles to my face. The Saracenes have lamed my arm, and the cut I received on my head has made me bald-headed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: All evidences of your valor, the finest ornaments of knighthood!

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: May be to a father! but the daughter is no Amazon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Be unconcerned. Wait here a little, I'll send Elsbeth to you, and then in God's name divulge to her the matter yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: It must be true, what has been said by the old poets; that valor becomes speechless before beau∣ty. It is easier to attack a horde of Arabs than to ad∣dress a fine damsel.—But here she comes—what shall I say to her?—Before I sat out for the holy Sepulchre the little thing played with the plume in my helmet—and now—she plays with my heart—casts it away perhaps, like broken toys.—Good Cuno! a smooth chin is more agreeable to women than a bald head. If an arm is too weak to throw it around a neck, they care but little whe∣ther it has been lamed by the cut of a Saracene—Wal∣ter! Walter! be on your guard! you have escaped the fetters of the infidels; if you fall into the snares of love, the absolution will avail you nothing, which you have so dearly purchased.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsbeth.
SP.P: Good day to you, valiant knight! My father sent me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: And without your father's command you would not have come to meet me?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Why not? you are an old friend of our house.

SP.SPEAKER: Waler.
SP.P: An old friend is often more welcome than a new lover?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb,
SP.P: You must know that bet∣ter than I.

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: So, so,—Do you know, my charming girl, that you are grown half a head taller, since I saw you last?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: And you are grown older, Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: So, so, that sounds edifying, how shall I take up the thread of conversation?— (loud) Yes, yes, time will even make an armour moulder. It is to me as if your charming cheerfulness had remained stick∣ing in your children's shoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Ah! I was so happy in my childhood!

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: Will your future life be less so?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: An old gipsy has foretold me many fine things, but I am afraid she has told me lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Walter,
SP.P: So, so—Tell me what the old one has pro∣phesied to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: She looked at my hand, love and pleasure, she said, every where, and the long line signifies: to the highest age.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Now, the love is found already.—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Yes, but the pleasure—

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Is Love's slave, and serves him willingly. You know, charming miss, why I am here?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My father told it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I wish your heart had told it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My father wishes that too.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I am, 'tis true, forty already; I cannot gain your heart by youthful attraction; my love is not of glow∣ing coals, but constant warmth; not of tinsel, but of stuff, woven with integrity and faith. I rave no more, know nothing of whim and humour, am to-morrow, like to-day, honest, without varnish. I cannot say more. Now tell me, what you think.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You are an honest man, I cannot deceive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Your pious eye speaks plain. You would not even deceive a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: If you value your happiness and mine, do not take me for your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Take? fy! you shall give yourself to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: That I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I thought so!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My father will compel me.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: He shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Pardon me!

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: What have I done to incur your hatred?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I hate no one, and you least; I love all mankind, and you before many.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: And yet—

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I will go into a convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Don't do that; for as little as I may be worth, in my castle is yet better living than in a convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: A vow binds me.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: To whom have you vowed.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: To the holy Agatha.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Look at me: Is that true?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: No, it is not true.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: A vow may bind you, but not to the holy Aga∣tha. Am I right, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I entreat your compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I don't know which of us is most in want of compassion. I would rather let you go to our Savior, than to a youth deserving of my envy.—With me it is all over! Farewel, my sweet dream! instead of a lovely wife, nobody will be about me but the castle priest; instead of the merry noise of my boys and girls, the hounds will howl in their kennel; good night, Wal∣ter? if you had not been so foolish as to go in your youth∣ful days on a pilgrimage to the holy sepulchre, you might have found a damsel, who one time would have strewed your grave with flowers. You have met with your desert! why did you go in quest of happiness to Pales∣tine? it dwells in every place where there is love!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Good man! I wish to see you happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Yes, if it can be done without you, is it not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I hear my father; ah! he will be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Had I but a child! even though it gave me cause of anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Now? have you settled mat∣ters?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Completely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Has the girl been bashful.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: That's well, Elsbeth. How do you like him.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Are you contented?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: If you are so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Yes, yes, dear girl! I am as much rejoiced as if I had to go to my own wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: So you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: If you want to celebrate a wedding in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: How mean you that?—I guess—you intend at your own castle?—I shall not suffer that! I am not rich, but to my Elsbeth's day of honor I give my last ounce of silver.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: You are mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Wherein?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: She will not have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What! do you make jest of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Far from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Did you not say just now that all was settled?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: That we shan't marry, is settled.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: That she without bashfulness—

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Has told me, that she could not love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And you—you cast down your eyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My father—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Is it true?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do not be angry!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P:
Naughty child! will there be every day such suitors? you are a poor girl, your smooth face is but a slender dowry. You also know that I cannot, lead you, dressed in silk and velvet, from one carousal to another, there to be stared and eyed at. You bloom here in ob∣scurity; no one sees you, no one knows you; the num∣ber of my friends is but small, for at my house there are
no festivals. You ought to thank your patron saint for having sent to you un upright man, who does not despise our poverty.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: No persuasion, knight. I love to see the hops voluntarily encircle the elm; but I do not like to see them tied to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Pooh! Pooh! a little constraint, and it soon be∣comes natural.—Elsbeth! prepare yourself: On All Saint's Day your wedding with this worthy man, will take place.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Father, I cannot! Let me retire into a convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Into a convent? Are you serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Yes, father, the sooner! the better! there I'll pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What will your prayers avail me? Those who do not act piously, pray.—I am old and weak, have no other support, and no other pleasure, but you—and me you will desert?—As I stood weeping at your mother's death bed; and with groans exclaimed: Who will now nurse me in my old age! the angel once more opened her eyes, smilingly pointed to you—and expi∣red.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Ah! my father!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I trusted to the promise of a dying wife. With consolation, I saw you grow up. Feeling my strength decline, I always said within myself, she will nurse me, she and my grand children; when attacked by the gout or lamed by the rheumatism, and unable to lift the spoon to my mouth, then she will feed me, she and my grand children.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Father! dear fa∣ther!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P:
When, on account of my fidelity to my liege Lord, the Count of Greyerz, the Emperor proscribed me; when the finest of my castles became destroyed and de∣molished, and I saw my property go to ruin; then I thought: If God pleases, my Elsbeth will be spared to me! and if she finds a good and rich husband, I will live with her, she will not let me suffer in my old age.—Alas! poor old man! she goes to a convent and prays, to the saints to help her father, whom she does not like to assist
herself.—Go! go! mother Gertraud will close my dy∣ing eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Father! you weep? (Turning hastily to Walter.) Knight, I'll be your wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I ought not to take advantage of this emotion; yet the sensibility, that leads you to my arms, is so pious and noble, that I draw from it sweet hopes for my future happiness. If such the daughter—how precious must be the wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: She is my daughter!—A mother's blessing and a father's thanks will accompany her to her new abode. When God intends to reward good children, he makes them benefactors to their parents!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: May your tears and the last smile of my mother always be before my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: May I offer this ring to my graceful bride.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Give it me, my son. (He takes the ring, puts it on Elsbeth's trembling finger, and joins their hands.) God bless you, and may your descendants flourish to the latest posterity!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What ails you?—Gertraud! Gertraud!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Don't call—have patience with me—it will soon be over—

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Recover yourself—retire to your chamber—
SP.STAGE: (The sound of a trumpet behind the scene.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Hah! the watchman on the steeple sounds the horn. We shall have guests at the wedding feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Not to-day, my father—only not to-day.—I am not able to receive your guests kindly.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Be tranquil, my lovely bride. You shall suffer no constraint.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: I am not well—indeed I am not!—but I shall soon be better. (She reels away, raises her eyes and hands towards heaven, and mutters to herself:) Ah, Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.STAGE: (Looks thoughtfully after her, and shakes his head.)
SP.P: I cannot rejoice in my good fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Content yourself, and give the bride time only, to drop the character of the maiden.

SP.SPEAKER: Attendant.
SP.P: An ambassador of the Count of Burgundy halts at the bridge, and desires to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: From the Count of Burgundy? what has he to do with me?—he has lost his way perhaps?

SP.SPEAKER: Attend.
SP.P: He enquired for Knight Cuno of Hallwyl.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: And the name of the ambassador.

SP.SPEAKER: Attend.
SP.P: Is Count Hugo of Werdenberg.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Incomprehensible. Let down the drawbridge; assist him to dismount, and conduct him here. (Exit attendant.) They do not speak well of the Count of Burgundy. Is it not the same that killed his brother Al∣brecht?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: It is said, that he is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: It's all the same. Also with his son I'll have no concern.

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: I am well acquainted with the Ambassador. In our youthful days we broke many a lance together. An embassy in which Count Hugo of Werdenberg is con∣cerned can be for no unworthy purpose.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Count HUGO, with a large retinue, among them HENRY as a page, hid among the crowd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Hail, noble Knight!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: You are welcome!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: I beg for a night's lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: As good as I can give.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Do I see right? Is not that Walter of Blonay?

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: 'Tis he.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: It's long since I saw you. How fare you?

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: The sun still shines into my garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Good luck to you. (Turning to Cuno.) Knight I have to deliver a message to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Speak in peace.—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Henry, Count of Burgundy, Lord of Arles, greets you, and requests your daughter, the noble Baro∣ness Elsbeth of Hallwyl, as his spouse.
SP.STAGE: (After a pause, during which Cuno and Walter regard each other with astonishment.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Knight not to mistrust your words, are you not mistaken?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Is your message indeed to Cuno of Hallwyl?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: To Cuno of Hallwyl.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: To the poor Cuno, whose property the Imperial proscription swallowed up? and who holds the last re∣mains of his castles in fief of a monk?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: To the same. Count Henry, my master, de∣sires no other dowry than your daughter's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Strange! by God! very strange! How can your Count have desire for a damsel, he never saw?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: She is not strange to him, he often saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Then he has been fluttering round her window with the swallows, for her foot never stepped beyond the limits of Hallwyl.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: No matter, he knows and loves her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I am sorry for it. Tell your master, that I think myself highly honored by his offer, yet my consent to his request is no more in my power, for my daughter is the bride of this worthy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: You perplex me. Knight Blonay, you often gained of me the price of arms, yet I always remained your friend, but I envy you for the wreath of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I have only seen the buds, perhaps the blossoms will prosper with you better.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: What do you mean by that? Do you doubt the honor of a knight?—Cuno of Hallwyl has never for∣feited his word, and Elsbeth bears your ring upon her finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: I expected that of you, noble knight, and thank you for it. But here is not the question, of what becomes you, or what pleases me?—I give you back your word; Elsbeth only can decide.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P:
God knows, how I doat on the damsel! yet were
she capable of deviating on this occasion, from the con∣duct which I demand and expect of her; I would tear her from my heart!—Go, page, and call my daugh∣ter. (A page goes off.) (To Hugo.) Knight, do not take it amiss, you know the laws of honor. If I cannot fulfil your wish, you are notwithstanding heartily wel∣come to my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: I have not lost all hopes yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: With permission, knight, how old is your lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: Nineteen years,

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Luck to them! Youth only plucks the roses of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Be resolute, they will yet blossom among your laurels.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsbeth.
SP.P: You have sent for me, father?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Come nearer. Here is Count Hugo of Wer∣denberg.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: He solicits your hand, in the name of his lord, the Count of Burgundy.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: You jest, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: It is earnest, Baroness. Permit me, to be the first, who pays his respects to the new Countess of Bur∣gundy, as my future sovereign.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Knight, you think me to be a child. Who is this Count of Burgundy? Do I know him? Have I ever heard of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: He loves you with warmth and honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: How can he love me? has he seen me in a dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: If you do not trust my words, accept these jew∣els, as a token of their truth. The Countess, Matilda, his mother, sends them to her beloved daughter-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Do you delight in my perplexity? Can my good father make jest of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Not at all! The proposal is serious, for with Hallwyl's daughter no one shall dare to sport. What I in duty had to say, I have said already; it is your turn, speak, the language of your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Ah father! you know, my heart is attached to one alone!—and that only one is lost to me!—Good Henry! If I am not to possess you, a throne has no at∣traction for me!—For your sake, father, I have given my word to this man, and I will keep it. (She offers Walter her hand, and then turns to Hugo.) Knight, tell your master, that Elsbeth of Hallwyl is betrothed.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Do not tell him so, knight! he would die with grief!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.STAGE: (Looking around her, and falling into a swoon.)
SP.P: Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno and Walter.
SP.P: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: My part is done. Count Henry, you must speak for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Away with the princely crown! Here I lay it down at Elsbeth's feet. She loved the poor Henry, and the poor Henry she shall again recognize, when she opens her lovely eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: I feel strange? Is not this Henry? the old her∣mit's son.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: The son of Count Albrecht of Burgundy, whose uncle slayed his father, and eighteen years withheld from him his parental inheritance.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Henry is it you?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Remember your vow, by the holy Agatha!

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: My Henry!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: You have refused my mother's jewels; behold the floweret lies within it which you gave me at our part∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Have I been dead? and now awake in heaven?

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Miracles! Where is brother Peter?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugo.
SP.P: He has methamorphosed himself into the knight Hans of Bonstetten.

SP.SPEAKER: Elsb.
SP.P: Father! For the love of God!—I cannot become this man's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P:
God forbid, that I should separate such a pair!
remain my friend, noble Miss, wear my ring as a remem∣brance of a faithful friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Take all my treasures! this one only leave to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Walt.
SP.P: Its love that gives it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: It is the finger of God!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry and Elsb.
SP.P: Your blessing, father!

SP.SPEAKER: Cuno.
SP.P: Take it with these tears of joy!

SP.SPEAKER: The Attendants.
SP.P: Long live the young Countess of Bur∣gundy!!!
